diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reactions (e.g., Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing fever, cough, and characteristic spots known as Koplik's spots, followed by a rash.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection preventable by vaccine that's especially dangerous for pregnant women due to risk of congenital rubella syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's most common in infants and young children.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus Infection
diagnoses.description: A common virus that can cause a range of illnesses, including cold-like symptoms, fever, pneumonia, diarrhea, and pink eye (conjunctivitis).

diagnoses.name: Epstein-Barr Virus (Infectious Mononucleosis)
diagnoses.description: A common virus that causes mononucleosis, known as 'mono' or 'the kissing disease,' which can result in fever, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can occur in people with strep throat, characterized by a bright red rash, fever, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the Toxoplasma gondii parasite, often resulting from contact with cat feces or undercooked meat.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, usually a reaction to a medication or an infection.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) Acute Infection
diagnoses.description: The early stage of HIV infection, presenting with symptoms like fever, sore throat, and rash as the virus rapidly multiplies.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.description: The second stage of syphilis, marked by skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: An infectious viral disease causing fever and a red rash, typically occurring in childhood.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection preventable by vaccine and known for its distinctive red rash.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.description: Also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease, causes a facial rash ('slapped cheek' rash) and may lead to anemia.

diagnoses.name: Dengue Fever
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne tropical disease caused by the dengue virus, noted for causing high fevers, severe headache, rash, and muscle and joint pain. Severe cases may cause hemorrhagic fever.

diagnoses.name: Zika Virus Infection
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by the Zika virus, spread primarily through the bite of an infected Aedes species mosquito, leading to mild symptoms including rash, conjunctivitis, and rarely, fever.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the chikungunya virus, characterized by fever and joint pain accompanied by rash and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial illness that develops in some people who have strep throat. Features a bright red rash covering the body.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body, famously known for its 'butterfly' rash on the face, along with fatigue and fever.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body, leading to symptoms like fever, rash, and conjunctivitis, particularly affecting children.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick, causing a rash, fever, and headache. It's considered the most severe form of rickettsial illness.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a range of symptoms including fever, leukopenia (due to autoimmune destruction of white cells), autoimmune hemolysis, and neuropsychiatric manifestations such as psychosis. Follicular hyperkeratosis isn't a hallmark but can be seen in dermatologic manifestations of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory condition can feature fever, rash which could be confused with or related to follicular hyperkeratosis, and leukopenia. While psychosis isn't a primary feature, systemic inflammation can lead to various neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia. Evans Syndrome can also manifest with leukopenia and systemic symptoms like fever, though psychosis and skin manifestations are less direct.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition primarily affects the skin and muscles, potentially causing follicular hyperkeratosis, and can include systemic features such as fever. An association with autoimmune hemolysis and leukopenia is less common but can occur due to overlap syndromes. Psychosis is not typically associated but could arise in severe systemic cases.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.rationale: A disorder of severe systemic inflammation and immune dysregulation, leading to fever, cytopenias including leukopenia, and potentially leading to neurological manifestations such as psychosis. Hemolysis may also occur. Skin involvement could mimic follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy complications, this autoimmune disorder can also lead to leukopenia, hemolytic anemia, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Skin manifestations can sometimes resemble follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can result in fever, hemolytic anemia, and leukopenia. Neurological complications including psychosis can occur in severe cases. Skin rash can be present but doesn’t commonly manifest as follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.rationale: This infection can cause fever, leukopenia, and autoimmune hemolysis. Psychotic symptoms are rare but neuropsychiatric manifestations could occur in severe cases. Skin rash can appear but is not typically described as follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis-associated aplastic anemia
diagnoses.rationale: A rare condition following acute hepatitis. Patients can present with leukopenia due to bone marrow aplasia, fever, and autoimmune hemolysis. Psychosis is uncommon but can result from severe illness or liver dysfunction. Skin changes are generally not associated with follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can present with fever, leukopenia (due to bone marrow involvement), autoimmune hemolysis, and even psychosis due to central nervous system involvement. Skin involvement can manifest in various ways, potentially mimicking follicular hyperkeratosis in some cases.

diagnoses: Epilepsy (for the symptom of seizure, if unrelated to infections or systemic conditions)
Rheumatoid arthritis (in rare cases can present with fever and thrombocytopenia)
Viral infections (such as Epstein-Barr virus, Cytomegalovirus)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's predominantly seen in children. The symptoms can mimic those listed but psoriasiform rash and follicular hyperkeratosis are less common.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various autoimmune disorders can cause fever, skin manifestations similar to psoriasiform rash, and potentially affect the nervous system causing seizures. Leukopenia can develop due to the immune response affecting white blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.description: Certain viral infections can present with fever, leukopenia due to the viral effect on bone marrow, skin rashes that might resemble psoriasis, and seizures particularly in severe cases or in individuals with weakened immune systems.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can present with fever, a rash that may appear psoriasiform, seizures due to neurological involvement, and leukopenia as a result of autoimmune destruction of blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Dermatologic Conditions
diagnoses.description: Certain severe dermatologic conditions, such as psoriasis itself, can lead to systemic symptoms like fever and potentially seizures. However, follicular hyperkeratosis and leukopenia would be more indirectly related or part of a systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: This condition, characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, can cause skin lesions resembling psoriasis, fever, and leukopenia. Seizures would be less common unless the CNS is involved.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: Conditions like Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis can cause systemic symptoms including fever and skin manifestations like psoriasiform rash. Leukopenia may be seen in severe cases or as a side effect of treatments. Seizures are less commonly directly associated.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV infection can present with fever, leukopenia as the virus affects the immune system, and various skin disorders, including those resembling psoriasis. Seizures may occur in advanced stages due to opportunistic infections affecting the CNS.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: Measles can cause a high fever, skin rash, and in severe cases, seizures, especially in children. Leukopenia can occur as a part of the body's response to the viral infection.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Certain types of lymphoma can present with fever, seizures (if the CNS is involved), skin lesions that may mimic psoriasiform rashes, and leukopenia due to bone marrow involvement.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Still's disease (Adult-onset Still's disease or AOSD)
Viral Infections (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, HIV)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, in the absence of other physical symptoms)
Primary angiitis of the central nervous system
Schizophrenia (in rare cases with severe fever and undiagnosed systemic illness)
Schizophrenia (in the context of associated medical conditions)
Infections causing atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS)
Dermatomyositis with associated interstitial lung disease
Infectious diseases (e.g., bacterial, viral, fungal, parasitic infections)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with widespread systemic manifestations including acute pericarditis, neuropsychiatric symptoms such as delirium, and kidney involvement leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can present with acute pericarditis, delirium due to septic emboli or the infection itself, and proteinuria as a sign of renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily known for muscle and skin involvement, it can cause follicular hyperkeratosis (as part of skin manifestation), and in severe cases, it can affect the heart leading to pericarditis and potentially cause delirium if there are central nervous system involvements or severe systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy
diagnoses.reasoning: Scurvy can cause follicular hyperkeratosis due to vitamin C deficiency. While less commonly associated with pericarditis or delirium, severe cases can present with a broad spectrum of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This autoimmune condition can display symptoms of several connective tissue diseases at once, including systemic lupus erythematosus and dermatomyositis, potentially causing acute pericarditis, delirium, proteinuria, and follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Secondary to the proteinuria; can occasionally lead to uremic pericarditis, with delirium occurring due to uremia, but follicular hyperkeratosis is not a primary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Specific viral infections can lead to acute pericarditis and delirium. Proteinuria might occur in the context of a systemic viral infection, and certain viral infections might lead to skin changes such as follicular hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause pericarditis and may lead to proteinuria due to kidney involvement. Delirium could be a part of severe systemic inflammatory response. Follicular hyperkeratosis is not directly associated but can be seen in a variety of systemic illnesses.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to myxedema, causing skin changes such as follicular hyperkeratosis. Severe untreated hypothyroidism might rarely contribute to pericardial effusion, potentially leading to acute pericarditis, and systemic effects may theoretically contribute to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria
diagnoses.reasoning: A group of disorders that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin manifestations like follicular hyperkeratosis. Acute attacks can cause delirium, and proteinuria can occur in cases of kidney involvement. Pericarditis is less common.

diagnoses: Systemic Onset juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (Still's Disease)
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with systemic involvement
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia combined with Immune Thrombocytopenia)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: A common condition that occurs when the immune system overreacts to allergens in the air. Symptoms can include sneezing, itching, nasal congestion, and coughing. Dermatographism and hypersensitivity reactions are related to this immune overreaction.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse reactions to medication can manifest in various ways, including dermatographism, hypersensitivity reactions, cough, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in your lymphatic system. It can cause lymphadenopathy, cough (due to pressure on the airways), and hypersensitivity reactions in some cases.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus impacts the immune system and can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy, dermatographism, and hypersensitivity reactions. Constipation and cough can also occur, especially as opportunistic infections or other conditions develop due to the weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, cough, and hypersensitivity reactions to certain triggers.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that is often a reaction to an infection or a drug. Symptoms can include hypersensitivity reactions and dermatographism, along with possible abdominal pain, which can mimic or cause constipation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including hypersensitivity reactions, dermatographism, lymphadenopathy, and potentially cough if the lungs are involved.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes severe damage to the lungs, digestive system, and other organs in the body. Symptoms include cough, constipation, and, in some cases, can lead to lymphadenopathy due to infection.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Symptoms can include constipation and could potentially cause lymphadenopathy through complications or associated systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from having too few healthy red blood cells due to a lack of iron in your body.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose).

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: An overactivity of one or more of the four parathyroid glands which can result in high levels of calcium in the blood and cause various symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: An intestinal disorder causing pain in the belly, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the bone marrow and affects the blood and sometimes other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A slow-growing blood cancer in which your bone marrow makes too many red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP)
diagnoses.description: An immune disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: A disease that causes the small blood vessels in your body to become inflamed and leak.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus grows outside your uterus.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
diagnoses.description: An infection of the female reproductive organs. It's usually caused by sexually transmitted bacteria.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder that increases the risk of blood clots. Symptoms can include thrombocytopenia, thromboembolic events, and potentially manifestations that may relate to physical sensitivities or pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause thrombocytopenia, vascular thrombosis, muscle pain, and various skin manifestations, possibly leading to cyst formation and hyperactivity due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. While not directly associated with most of the symptoms, PCOS can lead to systemic issues, and its indirect effects may contribute to a wide array of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms include thrombosis, pain, and various skin manifestations. The disease can cause various types of cysts due to inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, leading to thrombocytopenia among other symptoms. Associated with fatigue and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects the blood and blood vessels resulting in the destruction of blood platelets (thrombocytopenia), and can lead to kidney failure and other systemic symptoms including physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause thrombosis, thrombocytopenia, and muscle pain. Different types of vasculitis may also cause cysts and various skin and sensory complications.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Could potentially manifest as muscle pain, hyperactivity, and various sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. MS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including muscle pain and physical sensitivities. It is generally not associated with thrombocytopenia but can have a broad presentational spectrum.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Symptoms can include muscle pain and physical sensitivities, though it is not directly associated with thrombocytopenia or thromboembolic disease.

diagnoses.rationale: Gastroparesis, a condition that affects the normal spontaneous movement of the muscles in your stomach, can be a complication of diabetes, which might also be associated with hypertension.
Can cause gastroparesis due to damage to the nerves controlling the stomach, hypertension, and potentially exacerbate obsessive behaviors due to stress or anxiety related to the chronic condition.
Can result in hypertension and occasional vomiting, and the associated metabolic imbalances could indirectly contribute to or exacerbate mental health conditions.
Excessive anxiety or stress can lead to obsessive-compulsive behaviors, and stress can contribute to hypertension and adverse digestive symptoms like vomiting.
Depression can manifest with physical symptoms such as gastroparesis and vomiting, and it is often comorbid with conditions like obsessive-compulsive disorder.
This connective tissue disease can lead to gastroparesis, cause secondary hypertension, and potentially impact oral health, contributing to periodontal disease.
A group of disorders that can cause vomiting and hypertension, with the stress of dealing with a chronic condition potentially exacerbating or triggering obsessive-compulsive behavior.
Hypertension is both a cause and a complication of chronic kidney disease, which can lead to vomiting and potentially affect mental health due to the chronic nature of the disease.
Can lead to various symptoms including vomiting and hypertension, and the associated calcium imbalance might impact oral health, possibly contributing to periodontal disease.

Though primarily known for headaches, migraines can also cause symptoms like vomiting and have been associated with increased risk of hypertension. The chronic pain can influence mood, potentially exacerbating obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Familial Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by epistaxis, arteriovenous malformations (which could lead to neurological symptoms), and could be associated with polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: Primary polycythemia that may cause epistaxis due to increased blood volume and viscosity, can lead to neurological symptoms including neuropathies, and could potentially indirectly affect puberty timing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Though less common, it can present with polycythemia and may cause systemic symptoms like epistaxis. Neuropathies could arise due to disease or treatment effects.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause delayed puberty, may lead to sensory neuropathies, and might contribute to hyperactivity in certain pediatric cases though more commonly causes lethargy.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to neurological symptoms including sensory neuropathies. May indirectly affect puberty through overall health impact and has been associated with polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN1)
diagnoses.reasoning: Though not a direct cause, it can be associated with conditions leading to sensory neuropathies, hyperactivity, and various endocrinopathies causing delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Spherocytosis
diagnoses.reasoning: May present with polycythemia and can have episodic epistaxis. Indirectly linked to delayed puberty via anemia and overall health status.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Can present with epistaxis due to increased platelet count and has been associated with neurological symptoms, including neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause epistaxis and has been linked to delayed puberty. Hyperactivity is observed in pediatric cases, though typically associated with fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly causes delayed puberty in males and can be associated with a range of symptoms including those affecting neuropsychological health. Not directly associated with polycythemia or epistaxis but included for the constellation of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and mouth, which can lead to irritated eyes and difficulty focusing vision. It might also affect other organs and systems.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that leads to granulomas forming in various organs, including the eyes, skin, and lungs (leading to fibrosis), and can affect the nervous system influencing taste and smell (dysosmia).

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can lead to gastroparesis—delayed emptying of the stomach contents, diabetic retinopathy, and cataracts, which affect vision, and potentially diabetic neuropathy, which can impair taste and smell.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects many functions of the body, including movement, balance, and autonomic functions like digestion (possibly leading to gastroparesis) and can impact vision and sensory perception.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A degenerative disorder of the central nervous system that affects movement and often causes tremors. It can lead to gastroparesis. Olfactory dysfunction (dysosmia) is also a common non-motor symptom.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Autonomic Ganglionopathy
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, leading to a variety of symptoms including gastroparesis and possibly affecting sensory systems resulting in dysosmia and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic and ultimately fatal disease marked by a progressive decline in lung function. The fibrosis of lung tissue significantly reduces the oxygen exchange capacity, which might indirectly affect the cardiovascular system and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts within the liver, potentially leading to cirrhosis and fibrosis. May cause fatigue and dry eyes as part of Sicca syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by the inflammation of blood vessels and the formation of granulomas. It can lead to kidney failure, lung fibrosis, and involvement of the eyes and potentially affect the sensory system.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including visual disturbances and potentially impact on gastrointestinal motility, leading to gastroparesis.

diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) due to fibrosis
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (especially of the oral cavity, in the context of leukoplakia)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.rationale: Bronchitis, especially chronic bronchitis, is a key component of COPD.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause symptoms such as vomiting and could potentially exacerbate bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.rationale: While more commonly associated with bowel symptoms, it can also present with non-gastrointestinal symptoms such as physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
diagnoses.rationale: Endometriosis can contribute to the development of PID. Though PID does not directly cause bronchitis or leukoplakia, the systemic nature of an infection can affect overall health.

diagnoses.name: Oral Thrush
diagnoses.rationale: While not directly related to bronchitis or endometriosis, symptoms like leukoplakia can be confused with oral thrush.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Certain autoimmune conditions can present with a wide array of symptoms including physical sensitivities, gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting, and, in some cases, leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Lung
diagnoses.rationale: A patient with a history of bronchitis and symptoms such as leukoplakia, which might indicate a broader pattern of mucosal epithelial disruption, could be at risk.

diagnoses.name: Laryngopharyngeal Reflux
diagnoses.rationale: It can cause symptoms similar to GERD and potentially leukoplakia due to the irritation of mucous membranes.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.rationale: Though not directly correlated with bronchitis or leukoplakia, PCOS can be related to endometriosis and lead to a variety of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause vomiting and systemic symptoms due to malabsorption, which could lead to physical sensitivities.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder where mast cells are abnormally increased in multiple organs including the skin, bone marrow, gastrointestinal tract, and lymph nodes. It can cause symptoms similar to the ones described due to mast cell degranulation affecting various systems.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodes of severe swelling (angioedema) in various parts of the body, including the extremities, face, gastrointestinal tract, and airways. It may be accompanied by lymphadenopathy and is not typically associated with urticaria.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Patients often report symptoms such as postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS), sensitivities to chemicals, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting the connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Some subtypes can present with chest pain, POTS, and increased sensitivity to chemicals.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may coexist with conditions such as POTS and chemical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A syndrome by which patients have a severe sensitivity or allergy-like reaction to many different kinds of pollutants including solvents, VOCs (volatile organic compounds), perfumes, petrol, diesel, smoke, 'chemicals' in general, and often encompasses sensitivity to medication.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the body cannot properly regulate the number of immune cells. This causes the accumulation of lymphocytes and can lead to lymphadenopathy, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and involvement of the renal, neurological, and cardiovascular systems, including manifestations like chest pain and possibly POTS.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body. When you have lymphoma, lymphocytes change and grow out of control. This can cause lymphadenopathy among various other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, resulting in a wide range of chronic symptoms, possibly including anaphylaxis or near-anaphylaxis attacks. Symptoms reported can align with the mentioned combination, including chemical sensitivities and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a significant increase in heart rate when standing up, which can be associated with a variety of symptoms such as lightheadedness, fainting, and fatigue. Given as one of the primary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders in which part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, often leading to increased susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. It can be associated with POTS and impair immune function.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition involving multiple endocrine glands, often leading to hypothyroidism among other conditions. It can affect taste and immune functions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and mouth. It can lead to dysgeusia and is associated with an increased risk of infections due to impaired mucosal membranes.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that can cause dysgeusia and fatigue. It is sometimes associated with hypothyroidism and can affect immune response.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including those related to nutritional deficiencies that affect taste, immune function, and thyroid health.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands produce insufficient hormones. This can impact the immune system, metabolism, and potentially relate to POTS symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiency in Vitamin B12 can cause a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, weakness, susceptibility to infections, and dysgeusia. It can co-occur with hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can present with a wide range of symptoms, including those that affect autonomic functions and can mimic or exacerbate POTS symptoms, as well as impact the immune system.
Endometriosis
diagnoses.detail: A disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of the uterus grows outside the uterus, causing pain and possibly infertility.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.detail: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms may worsen with physical or mental activity but don't improve with rest.

diagnoses.description: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.detail: A common disorder affecting the large intestine, causing cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, and constipation. It's considered to be a chronic condition that needs to be managed long term.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.detail: A disorder marked by severe allergic or sensitivity reactions to environmental substances, chemicals, or pollutants at levels that are generally considered safe for the majority of people.

diagnoses.description: Cyclical Vomiting Syndrome
diagnoses.detail: A condition characterized by episodes of severe vomiting that have no apparent cause. Episodes can last for hours or days and alternate with symptom-free periods.

diagnoses.description: Migraine
diagnoses.detail: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, notably severe, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.description: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.detail: A condition characterized by hormonal imbalance and metabolism problems affecting women of reproductive age, potentially leading to irregular menstrual periods, and infertility.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.detail: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, sleep problems, fatigue, and often emotional and mental distress.

diagnoses.description: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.detail: A sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep, leading to daytime fatigue and other symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.detail: A chronic digestive disease in which stomach acid or bile irritates the food pipe lining, leading to acid reflux and symptoms such as heartburn or vomiting.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Conversion Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental condition that causes patients to experience neurological symptoms, such as pseudoseizures, without a neurological diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A disorder causing repetitive episodes of complete or partial obstructions of the upper airway during sleep, leading to breathing interruptions.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach acid comes up into the esophagus, leading to vomiting and irritation.

diagnoses.name: Seasonal Allergies
diagnoses.description: Allergies that occur at a particular time of the year and can cause irritated eyes, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and noise. It could be related indirectly to eye irritation and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Central Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A disorder where your breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep due to a lack of respiratory effort.

diagnoses.name: Sturge-Weber Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare congenital neurological and skin disorder. It is often associated with port-wine stains of the face, glaucoma, seizures, and intellectual disability.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes severe episodes of unilateral cranial pain accompanied by symptom like redness of the eye on the affected side.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and can cause frequent nosebleeds, internal bleeding, and iron-deficiency anemia.

diagnoses.name: Klippel-Trenaunay Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare congenital medical condition in which blood vessels and/or lymph vessels fail to form properly. It could potentially lead to vascular anomalies visible on the skin surface.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Rhinosinusitis
diagnoses.description: Chronic inflammation of the sinuses, potentially causing post-nasal drip, hypersensitivity reactions, and cognitive dysfunction due to chronic poor sleep or frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A disorder causing frequent waking during the night, which may result in daytime cognitive dysfunction. Hypersensitivity reactions and post-nasal drip could be related to coexisting conditions or environmental factors.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Cognitive dysfunction (sometimes referred to as "fibro fog") and hypersensitivity reactions are common. Though not characterized by fibrosis, its symptoms overlap with those listed.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction that causes cold-like symptoms including post-nasal drip, hypersensitivity reactions, and frequent waking due to discomfort. Can indirectly affect cognitive functions through poor sleep quality.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder that often leads to post-nasal drip, which may exacerbate or be associated with symptoms such as hypersensitivity reactions. If severe, sleep disruption and cognitive dysfunction may occur due to discomfort and frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by lung scarring that worsens over time, causing difficulties in breathing. While directly causing fibrosis, it can lead to frequent waking due to breathlessness. Cognitive dysfunction may occur secondary to oxygen deprivation or chronic fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It is associated with systemic symptoms, including fatigue and cognitive dysfunction, and may present with hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that doesn't improve with rest and worsens with physical or mental activity. Symptoms can include cognitive dysfunction and sleep abnormalities like frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to energy metabolism disruptions. Symptoms can include cognitive dysfunction, hypersensitivity reactions, and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including cognitive dysfunction, hypersensitivity reactions, and potentially fibrosis in various organs.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry mouth and dry eyes, which can lead to oral pain and sinutitis. Patients may also experience swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) and various hypersensitivity reactions. Cognitive dysfunction, presenting as memory problems, has been reported in Sjögren's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body. Symptoms can include oral pain, lymphadenopathy, and hypersensitivity reactions. Neuropsychiatric SLE can lead to memory problems, and patients may also report signs of sinusitis due to mucosal involvement.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus can cause a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy, oral pain due to opportunistic infections like candidiasis, memory problems as part of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorders, and hypersensitivity reactions to medications or the virus itself. Sinusitis can also occur in immunocompromised patients.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that often affects the lungs, skin, or lymph nodes. Lymphadenopathy is a common finding, and it can present with symptoms like hypersensitivity reactions to an unknown trigger. Neurosarcoidosis may lead to memory problems, and involvement of the upper respiratory tract can cause sinutitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While not common, it can lead to secondary Sjögren's syndrome, causing oral pain and increased risk of sinus infections. Lymphadenopathy and hypersensitivity reactions to the disease or its treatment can occur, and cognitive symptoms like memory problems have been reported.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that can cause lymphadenopathy and oral pain in its secondary stage. The tertiary stage can lead to gummas, which may be painful and can contribute to sinusitis. Neurosyphilis can result in memory problems and other cognitive impairments.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by Borrelia burgdorferi. Patients can experience lymphadenopathy, hypersensitivity reactions like erythema migrans, and memory problems as part of Lyme neuroborreliosis. Oral pain and sinutitis are less commonly reported but possible due to the disease's spread and immune response.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Lymphadenopathy is a common symptom, especially in extrapulmonary tuberculosis. Patients might experience oral pain due to tuberculous ulcers, memory problems if the central nervous system is involved, and sinusitis due to spread of the infection.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, including memory problems. While not commonly associated with lymphadenopathy, hypersensitivity reactions, oral pain, or sinutitis, these symptoms can occur secondary to the disease or its treatments.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood or bone marrow characterized by an abnormal increase in white blood cells. Lymphadenopathy is a common sign; patients may also experience oral pain due to mucositis caused by the disease or its treatment, and hypersensitivity reactions to treatment. Memory problems may occur as a result of the disease or neurotoxic effects of chemotherapy. Sinutitis can occur due to neutropenia and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation due to underlying bronchitis
Infectious diseases (e.g., Viral or bacterial infections)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (in the context of leukoplakia)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Migraine (for migratory edema as a rare manifestation)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) / Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often presents with dry eyes and dry mouth, which could explain the onychodystrophy due to associated skin dryness, fatigue due to systemic involvement, and potentially angioedema as part of an atypical presentation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, commonly presenting with fatigue, vascular anomalies, skin changes including onychodystrophy, and potentially angioedema as part of its various manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that affects joints but can also have systemic manifestations including vasculature involvement (vascular anomalies), fatigue, and eye dryness due to secondary Sjögren's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including fatigue, vascular anomalies, and potentially onychodystrophy and eye involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to fatigue, dry skin (potentially affecting nail health), and occasionally angioedema due to myxedema.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune skin disorder that can lead to onychodystrophy, fatigue if the disease is severe and systemic, and dry eyes either directly or due to associated ocular conditions.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting connective tissues, manifesting in skin, joints, and blood vessel anomalies, which might present with vascular anomalies, fatigue, and potentially related onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin (onychodystrophy potential), eyes (dry eyes), lungs (leading to fatigue), and rarely vascular system and with possible angioedema in an atypical presentation.

diagnoses.name: Fabry Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that can lead to angiokeratomas (vascular anomalies), fatigue, potential eye manifestations, and might indirectly affect nail health.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition that causes recurring episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). While the primary symptom is angioedema, systemic involvement including fatigue and potentially vascular anomalies might be seen.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Non-syndromic genetic hearing loss and deafness

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Acute Monocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A form of leukemia characterized by a rapid increase in abnormal monocytes. May manifest through symptoms like monocytosis, delayed puberty due to malnutrition or organ infiltration, and oral manifestations like periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A slow-progressing type of leukemia characterized by monocytosis. Symptoms can include gum disease due to poor immune response, delayed puberty in children, and mild nonspecific symptoms like headache.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs, particularly the lungs and lymph nodes. May present with laryngitis due to laryngeal involvement, periodontal disease as a rare manifestation, and nonspecific symptoms like headache.

diagnoses.name: Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting children, causing inflammation in joints and potentially other parts of the body. Can lead to delayed puberty and may have systemic symptoms like monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive and produces insufficient hormones, leading to delayed puberty, possibly contributing to periodontal disease due to altered metabolism, and nonspecific symptoms like headaches.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome can cause a wide range of symptoms due to immunosuppression, including oral health problems like periodontal disease, recurrent laryngitis, and more general symptoms like headache.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation of the blood vessels, which can lead to symptoms like sinusitis, which might present with periodontal disease, as well as systemic symptoms such as headache, and possible monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder that affects multiple parts of the body, including the mouth, leading to periodontal disease, headaches, and possibly other symptoms aligning with the ones listed.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It can cause systemic symptoms such as headache, and in rare instances, can lead to oral manifestations or delayed puberty due to overall health deterioration.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare cancer that can produce lesions in various parts of the body, including bones, skin, and gums, potentially leading to periodontal disease, and systemic symptoms like headache.

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition that often results from stress and presents similarly to a heart attack, with no coronary artery blockage.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time, which can affect the body's ability to clean your blood, filter extra water out of your blood, and control your blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by forced and involuntary blinking or spasm of the eyelids.

diagnoses.name: Angioedema
diagnoses.description: An area of swelling of the lower layer of skin and tissue just under the skin or mucous membranes. The swelling may occur in the face, throat, and abdomen, and may be life-threatening if airway obstruction occurs.

diagnoses.name: Dysosmia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by a distorted sense of smell; individuals may smell odors that aren't actually present or may perceive existing odors in a distorted way.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: A broad category of diseases where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues, potentially linking to or exacerbating conditions like angioedema and potentially impacting kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Stress-related Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that are directly influenced or exacerbated by stress, including psychological and physical health issues such as Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy and potentially exacerbating conditions like CKD.

diagnoses.name: Neurological Conditions
diagnoses.description: Diseases of the brain, spine, and the nerves that connect them. This includes conditions such as blepharospasm which is a form of dystonia, and other diseases that might affect sensory perception like dysosmia.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Reactions that can range from mild to severe, impacting various organs and systems, potentially underlying angioedema and could be a factor in dysosmia if there are sinus or nasal issues.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders of the endocrine system, the system that regulates hormones. Hormonal imbalances can influence various conditions, including the progression of chronic kidney disease and potentially interact with symptoms like dysosmia.

diagnoses: Chronic Hepatitis B or C Infection
Secondary Polycythemia due to Obstructive Sleep Apnea

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related condition where the immune system responds to allergens, causing symptoms such as sneezing, itchiness, and irritated eyes. It could potentially explain hypersensitivity reactions and some of the other symptoms mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that attacks glands producing saliva and tears. It leads to dry mouth and eyes, which can cause oral pain, irritated eyes, and possibly affect taste.

diagnoses.name: Bell's Palsy
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles. It can affect the taste senses (dysgeusia) and potentially cause oral pain, in addition to impacting the eyelid's ability to close (irritated eyes).

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This deficiency can lead to neurological issues, which might explain tinnitus and dysgeusia (altered taste). It could also indirectly affect oral health and contribute to oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Zinc plays a crucial role in taste perception and immune function. Deficiency can lead to dysgeusia and potentially contribute to hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: This digestive disorder can lead to symptoms such as dysgeusia due to acid reflux and can cause oral pain. Whilst not directly linked with tinnitus or hypersensitivity, the discomfort and stress associated with GERD might exacerbate these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a variety of symptoms including dysgeusia. High blood sugar levels can result in gum disease, leading to oral pain. It may also cause dry mouth which can irritate the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness affecting the central nervous system. It can lead to sensory disturbances (perhaps explaining dysgeusia and tinnitus) and potentially contribute indirectly to other symptoms through its broad effects on health.

diagnoses.name: Temporomandibular Joint Disorders (TMJ)
diagnoses.description: Disorders affecting the jaw joint and chewing muscles can cause oral pain and may contribute to tinnitus. Dysgeusia can occur as a secondary symptom due to pain and discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Dental Abscesses
diagnoses.description: These are pockets of pus that can form in teeth or gums due to bacterial infection, causing significant oral pain, and could potentially affect taste. They might also contribute to general irritation and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Gastrointestinal infections or obstructions causing vomiting
Acute abdomen conditions (e.g., appendicitis, pancreatitis) with secondary symptoms
Toxic ingestions or exposures leading to multiple system effects
Endocrine disorders (e.g., Addison's disease) with electrolyte imbalances causing vomiting
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) with multi-organ involvement
Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
Dehydration due to vomiting and diarrhea
COVID-19 (considering gastrointestinal symptoms and hypoxia as clinical manifestations)
Autoimmune disorders (with cutaneous manifestations leading to pruritis)
Urinary tract infection (considering the incontinence and potential for systemic infection leading to hypotension)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scintillation) and other neurological symptoms before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a constant ache or pressure around the head, especially at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes intense headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, and can be accompanied by nasal congestion and a watery eye.

diagnoses.name: Medication Overuse Headache
diagnoses.description: Headaches resulting from the overuse of medication to treat headache symptoms, leading to a cycle of worsening headaches.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that can cause a headache, usually along with fever, nasal congestion, and facial pressure.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain that can cause headaches, often accompanied by other symptoms like changes in vision or neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by increased pressure inside the skull causing headaches and visual problems without an obvious cause.

diagnoses.name: Cervicogenic Headache
diagnoses.description: A headache caused by a disorder of the cervical spine and its component bones, discs, muscles, and/or nerves.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: A condition causing inflammation of the arteries in and around the scalp, resulting in a severe headache, often with symptoms including scalp tenderness and visual disturbance.

diagnoses: Glioma or other primary brain tumors

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and time-dependent gothic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache with symptoms such as pulsing sensation, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. An aura can occur before or with the headache, with visual disturbances like flashes of light or blind spots, or other disturbances such as tingling on one side of the face or in an arm or leg and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood flow to the brain. It's often a warning sign of a future stroke and is characterized by sudden weakness, speech difficulty, and loss of vision, among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor involves a growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, speech problems, weakness, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). MS causes communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body. Symptoms include fatigue, weakness, visual disturbances, and issues with coordination and speech.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: Primary progressive aphasia is a rare neurological syndrome that impairs language capabilities. People with this condition experience a gradual loss of language function, including speaking, reading, writing, and understanding language, as the first symptom.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. While not all symptoms directly match, in complex cases, it could present with these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: An intracerebral hemorrhage is a type of stroke caused by bleeding within the brain tissue itself – a life-threatening situation. Symptoms can include a sudden, severe headache, weakness, numbness, vision problems, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. The inflammation can cause symptoms such as confusion, a fever, a headache, seizures, problems with senses or movement, or difficulty with speech.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A subtype of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scotoma) before the onset of headache.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a dull, aching pain and can be accompanied by sensitivity to light or sound, but not usually with nausea or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that produces severe headaches on one side of the head. It can be associated with symptoms like red or watery eyes, runny or stuffy nose, and swelling around the eye, but less commonly with nausea, weakness, or photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted, leading to symptoms such as weakness, difficulty speaking, and in some cases, headache, nausea, or problems with vision like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can cause weakness, difficulty speaking, and in some cases, headache or visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like weakness, numbness, a loss of muscle coordination, and issues with vision.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms like headaches, nausea, seizures, weakness, or visual problems depending on the tumor’s location.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms can include headache, fever, nausea, weakness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from a restricted blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include dizziness, double vision, slurred speech, and in some cases, migraine-like headaches with associated symptoms such as nausea and visual disturbances.

diagnoses: Brain tumor or central nervous system neoplasms

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may include visual disturbances, aphasia, or motor weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition in which poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include headache, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, where symptoms similar to a stroke occur but last only for a short time. This includes headaches, weakness, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. It may present with headache, weakness, seizures, and difficulties with speech.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and slurred speech.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine headache where there is a temporary weakness on one side of the body prior to or accompanying the headache. Symptoms can mimic a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, including possibly loss of awareness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. The inflammation can lead to symptoms like headaches, fever, and neck stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, which can cause flu-like symptoms, including a headache, weakness, confusion, seizures, and problems with senses or movement.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Symptoms may include a sudden, severe headache, weakness, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Epilepsy (for seizures, related to underlying conditions)
Chronic Kidney Disease related to systemic disease
Steven-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (considering medication or infection as triggers)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction (including sulfa drugs, anticonvulsants, NSAIDs)
Hepatitis B or C associated nephritis
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.details: A disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever and can affect the heart, joints, skin, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause various skin rashes, including erythema migrans, and affect the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.details: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Rickettsia rickettsii, characterized by a rash that may start as small, flat, pink, non-itchy spots on the wrists and ankles.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.details: An acute, febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children. It is a form of vasculitis, where blood vessels throughout the body become inflamed.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.details: A virus that commonly causes illness in children, such as erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) and can lead to hemolytic anemia in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.details: An inflammatory arthritis characterized by high fevers, rash, and joint pain. It can affect both children (Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis) and adults.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.details: The second stage of syphilis, marked by skin rashes and mucous membrane lesions. Untreated, syphilis can progress to more severe stages and affect multiple organ systems.

diagnoses.name: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A condition that affects the blood and blood vessels. It results in the destruction of blood platelets, hemolytic anemia, and kidney failure due to damage to the very small blood vessels of the kidneys.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Hemolytic Anemia
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Viral Infections (HIV, Hepatitis C, Epstein-Barr Virus)
Epilepsy (due to CNS involvement in systemic diseases)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, EBV, Hepatitis C)
Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
